txt.en: 'May Go Vahn In.'
Accompany Ravaedron as he bids farewell
'Who is your new friend, Ravaedron?'
Talk to Maddoc Stagshorn
Visit with the Stagshorns as Ravaedron bids farewell
Talk to Glenys Stagshorn inside Fernbrake Cot
Talk to Maddoc Stagshorn inside Fernbrake Cot
'Mae govannen!'
Ravaedron is outside Fernbrake Cot, the home of his friends the Stagshorns.
Stand with Ravaedron and provide him the comfort he needs as he bids farewell.
Maddoc Stagshorn has welcomed you to Fernbrake Cot.
'You will find the Stagshorns most agreeable, my friend. They are a charming couple, and their son Bran is quite a lively lad.\n\n'I will let them know we are here.'
Ravaedron has asked you to accompany him as he bids farewell to his friends the Stagshorns, before he leaves Middle-earth forever.
DNT - Blah!
'Come inside, come inside! There are few roads in this land, and you must be weary from your travels!'
Stand with Ravaedron and provide him the comfort he needs as he bids farewell.

'Have you known Ravaedron long? We met him only recently, but he is dear to us, and the tales he has told us of long ago times and distant places have captured our imaginations! Did he ever find the prey he sought, the dark-robed villains that drew him to the Angle?

'We are sworn to secrecy, and will speak of them to no one else. But I confess the nighttime shadows seemed deeper after he spoke of the horseless riders loose in the wild!

'Still, we fear them not. My husband and I come from tough stock; none could long live in this land without being made hardy, or beginning so!'
'Ravaedron! You're back!'
'Aye.'
'Mother! Father! Ravaedron's back!'
The air has grown chilly inside Fernbrake Cot.\n\nMaddoc Stagshorn motions for you to speak with him.

'I am sorry you had to see that, [placeholder]. It pains me to say this, but perhaps Ravaedron was not as close a friend as we thought. His people and ours must simply be too different.\n\n'Did he befriend us... out of pity? Do all long-lived folk look upon the men and women of the Angle as mere mayflies, alive for so short a time they must be safe-guarded and shown sympathy? I thought our friendship with Ravaedron was different, but I suppose it was not.'
'I have been looking for the wraiths as well!'
'If I find them, they had better watch out!'
'I haven't told anyone!'
'Is that... is that why you came back?'
'For how long?'
'Why?'
Glenys Stagshorn has welcomed you inside her home.
'Don't you like it here?'
'I am nearly a man grown!'

'I am sorry you had to see that, [placeholder]. It pains me to say this, but perhaps Ravaedron was not as close a friend as we thought. Your people and ours must simply be too different.\n\n'Did he befriend us... out of pity? Do all long-lived folk look upon the men and women of the Angle as mere mayflies, alive for so short a time they must be safe-guarded and shown sympathy? I thought our friendship with Ravaedron was different, but I suppose it was not.'
'What do your folk say? Maygo Vahnen?'
'It is good to see you again, young Bran.'
'My mission was intended to remain a secret, Bran.'
'Well, any friend of yours is a friend of ours.'
'Are your parents at home?'
'Listen, my friends. I did not mean...'
'No.'
'That is quite close, my friends.'
'Maddoc... Glenys...'
'I came to say good-bye, for I will be leaving these shores.'
'Mae... govannen...'
'Of course, but... it is complicated for me.'
'This is [placeholder], an adventurer lately come to Mitheithel.'
'But fear not: you will be protected even after I am gone.'
'I was hoping to introduce you.'
'Of course... but I still wanted to make arrangements for your safety.'
'Dangers encroach even upon lands once thought secure...'
'I think there has been a misunderstanding. Please allow me to explain.'
'You have not seen such dangers in Mitheithel as I have, and...'
'Bran!'
'When Elves leave Middle-earth, they leave for good, don't they?'
'We can take care of ourselves.'
'Do all Elves treat their friends this way?'
'That is what concerns you?'
'Do you think so little of us? We did not befriend you to keep us safe!'
'So we are like children to you?'
'I think you had better leave, Ravaedron.'
Instance: A Parting
Talk to Ravaedron outside Fernbrake Cot
